author: thiago_crowdtainer
content:
hey there , quick question: is there something peculiar to PoS that makes having one majority client (EL) worse off than when compared to having one majority client in PoW ?
I'm basically trying to understand why having all the newer EL's should be a pre-requisite for the merge (its seems more a nice-to-have, given the status quo is already majority geth). It seems both goals are completely orthogonal and can/should be tried in parallel. Am I missing something?

Unless the merge is no longer the highest priority (but client diversity is the highest priority now), then its fine, but we should state it clearly instead of artificially delaying the merge or artifially pressuring newer EL teams to be on par with geth maturity.. With a few exceptions, it seems pretty clear from the last all core devs call that the newer EL teams don't feel confident to claim (in soonish timeframe) they are ready for production use with high stakes validators / CL's connected to them. While the CL seems ready to go. To be clear: this is not a criticism towards any clients, I'm just trying to understand the decisions taken.

author: chris2_2_2
content:
Diversify leads to strength and promotes honesty. If geth team has an exploit they‚Äôve programmed to takeover the eth network having 3 other clients keeps that from happening. Eth had always done their best to push users to diversify. 

Plus if one goes down exchanges can switch to the second as has happened before.

Also it‚Äôs nice if your backend is all in the same code.

author: thiago_crowdtainer
content: I'm not sure how to be more clear, butI'm not questioning the importance of client diversity (I agree it is important). My question is related to (EL!) diversity in relation to PoW vs PoS, and whether this should really be some pre-requisite for the merge at this point in time.

author: chris2_2_2
content: I‚Äôd assume for the biggest change you‚Äôd want the most diversify/safety incase something goes wrong. So many protocols have been hacked or suffered issues even if they passed multiple audits. I suspect there will be things that go wrong and despite so many checks there have been issues on merge testnets. So best we be as safe as possible which is what‚Äôs being done.

author: thiago_crowdtainer
content: as far as I can tell, the most important client diversity wrt PoS transition is diversity in CL clients, which we already have. For EL, status quo is already geth and thus far I don't see a technical reason why it should change with PoS. IMO we should persue EL diversity, but as an orthogonal matter (and not pre-requisite for merge).  One could also make the argument that you'd have less chances of things going wrong by using the most battle-tested EL first, and then over time transition to other clients as they mature and get better tested (after the merge). The risk of running into  EL bugs in the newer clients is not zero and shouldn't be underestimated either.

author: chris2_2_2
content: Eth has already recommended exchanges run 2 EL clients for a backup. Some exchanges dapps etc don‚Äôt run geth. Also some people like Rust üòõ
